articles.headline: Letting Fliers Have a Voice in Mergers
articles.snippet: As the potential merger of US Airways and American Airlines percolates, one interested party is left on the sidelines: the consumers.
articles.abstract: As the potential merger of US Airways and American Airlines percolates, one interested party is left on the sidelines: the consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every time a company goes through bankruptcy court or gets involved in merger talks, it’s disappointing to see who does not have a seat at the negotiating table.

articles.headline: Spain Is Still Awaiting the Payoff From Austerity
articles.snippet: Stringent fiscal policy has failed to attract global bond investors to Greece, Ireland and Portugal, and the approach is now being severely tested in Spain.
articles.abstract: Stringent fiscal policy has failed to attract global bond investors to Greece, Ireland and Portugal, and the approach is now being severely tested in Spain.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Since the beginning of the debt crisis in Europe more than two years ago, defenders of the euro currency union have stuck to a basic argument: if the euro zone’s weaker economies would only keep pursuing policies of austerity, even as growth collapsed and job losses mounted, they would be rewarded by investors more willing to buy their bonds.

articles.headline: In Virginia, 2 Ex-Governors Vie for Senate and Balance of Power
articles.snippet: George Allen, a Republican, and Tim Kaine, a Democrat, are in a tight race for a seat both sides see as potentially decisive when it comes to party control of the Senate.
articles.abstract: George Allen, a Republican, and Tim Kaine, a Democrat, are in a tight race for a seat both sides see as potentially decisive when it comes to party control of the Senate.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — Seven months before Virginia voters elect their next United States senator, former Gov. Tim Kaine, the Democrats’ choice for the slot, was rallying a college crowd here, trying to impress upon them the magnitude of the decision to come.

articles.headline: In Search of Apps for Television
articles.snippet: The technology industry is working on viewing options that could include apps, a move that has the potential to transform cable television’s interface and business model.
articles.abstract: The technology industry is working on viewing options that could include apps, a move that has the potential to transform cable television’s interface and business model.
articles.lead_paragraph: The same consumers who delight in navigating the iPad still click frustratingly through cable channels to find a basketball game. Their complaint: Why can’t television be more like a tablet?
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Nick Wingfield

articles.headline: U.S. Antitrust Move Has Google Fighting on Two Fronts
articles.snippet: A potential case by the Federal Trade Commission, which hired a former prosecutor to lead its effort, could embolden European Union officials in their own antitrust investigation.
articles.abstract: A potential case by the Federal Trade Commission, which hired a former prosecutor to lead its effort, could embolden European Union officials in their own antitrust investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google may soon be fighting antitrust battles on two fronts.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld and Edward Wyatt

articles.headline: United States Talks Fail as Pakistanis Seek Apology
articles.snippet: Negotiations between the United States and Pakistan failed over Pakistani demands for an apology for American airstrikes last November that killed 24 Pakistani soldiers on the Afghan border.
articles.abstract: Negotiations between the United States and Pakistan failed over Pakistani demands for an apology for American airstrikes last November that killed 24 Pakistani soldiers on the Afghan border.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The first concentrated high-level talks aimed at breaking a five-month diplomatic deadlock between the United States and Pakistan ended in failure on Friday over Pakistani demands for an unconditional apology from the Obama administration for an airstrike. The White House, angered by the recent spectacular Taliban attacks in Afghanistan, refuses to apologize.
articles.byline: By Declan Walsh, Eric Schmitt and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: Death of Spy, Zipped Into Bag, Spawns Theories and Inquest
articles.snippet: An inquest has brought forth details of the death in August 2010 of Gareth Williams, who was found locked in a duffel bag in a bathtub.
articles.abstract: An inquest has brought forth details of the death in August 2010 of Gareth Williams, who was found locked in a duffel bag in a bathtub.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain, home to the MI6 spy agency that inspired the James Bond stories and the billion-dollar film franchise, has been wrestling this week with one of the country’s strangest real-life spy mysteries in a generation, one that has become known popularly as the case of the spy in the bag.

articles.headline: O.K., Google, Take a Deep Breath
articles.snippet: At a company known for a hard-driving culture, a seven-week course in mindfulness techniques is giving employees a better way to cope.
articles.abstract: At a company known for a hard-driving culture, a seven-week course in mindfulness techniques is giving employees a better way to cope.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mountain View, Calif.

articles.headline: A Humbled Gap Tries a Fresh Coat of Pep
articles.snippet: After defining 1990s khaki culture, the clothing chain stumbled. Now it’s trying new ways to build sales — like making stores cheerier and its ad campaign brighter.
articles.abstract: After defining 1990s khaki culture, the clothing chain stumbled. Now it’s trying new ways to build sales — like making stores cheerier and its ad campaign brighter.
articles.lead_paragraph: THIS can’t be a Gap: the mannequins look kind of happy.

articles.headline: Telling Strength From Weakness
articles.snippet: A former Fed governor who served during the financial crisis says big banks need to make clearer, more expansive disclosures.
articles.abstract: A former Fed governor who served during the financial crisis says big banks need to make clearer, more expansive disclosures.
articles.lead_paragraph: ARE the perils posed by too-big-to-fail banks a thing of the past?

articles.headline: Daring Circle, Now at Risk, Aided Activist’s Flight in China
articles.snippet: Chen Guangcheng’s rush for freedom from house arrest was made possible by a small network of people, risking detention, who used code to elude a pervasive surveillance apparatus.
articles.abstract: Chen Guangcheng’s rush for freedom from house arrest was made possible by a small network of people, risking detention, who used code to elude a pervasive surveillance apparatus.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — For months, Chen Guangcheng, one of China’s best-known dissidents, played a cat-and-mouse game with the phalanx of guards encircling his home. He dug a tunnel to try to escape, a friend says, but was found out. And he sneaked out a video that alerted his supporters to the smothering confinement he said he and his wife endured at the hands of the men who kept them virtual prisoners in their rural farmhouse.

articles.headline: How Apple Sidesteps Billions in Taxes
articles.snippet: Apple serves as a window on how technology giants have taken advantage of tax codes written for an industrial age and ill suited to today’s digital economy.
articles.abstract: Apple serves as a window on how technology giants have taken advantage of tax codes written for an industrial age and ill suited to today’s digital economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: RENO, Nev. — Apple, the world’s most profitable technology company, doesn’t design iPhones here. It doesn’t run AppleCare customer service from this city. And it doesn’t manufacture MacBooks or iPads anywhere nearby.
articles.byline: By Charles Duhigg and David Kocieniewski

articles.headline: Brain Drain Feared as German Jobs Lure Southern Europeans
articles.snippet: The recruitment of young, skilled southern Europeans has led to concerns that Germany is gaining another economic advantage over financially ailing European Union countries.
articles.abstract: The recruitment of young, skilled southern Europeans has led to concerns that Germany is gaining another economic advantage over financially ailing European Union countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: SCHWÄBISCH HALL, Germany — While much of southern Europe is struggling with soaring unemployment rates, a robust Germany is desperate for educated workers, and it has begun to look south for the solution.
articles.byline: By Suzanne Daley and Nicholas Kulish

articles.headline: For Edwards and Aide, Another Lost Love Story
articles.snippet: John Edwards, the former Democratic senator who is facing 30 years in prison, leaned forward and watched as Andrew Young, the man who had held his deepest secret, sat on the witness stand.
articles.abstract: John Edwards, the former Democratic senator who is facing 30 years in prison, leaned forward and watched as Andrew Young, the man who had held his deepest secret, sat on the witness stand.
articles.lead_paragraph: GREENSBORO, N.C. — For hour after grueling hour, Andrew Young sat on the witness stand in a small federal courtroom here last week and stared straight ahead, never once facing the man he had once looked upon as a father.

articles.headline: Recall Election Tests Strategies for November
articles.snippet: The vote on recalling Wisconsin’s governor has become a rallying point for unions and business interests that oppose them, but it is only a warm-up.
articles.abstract: The vote on recalling Wisconsin’s governor has become a rallying point for unions and business interests that oppose them, but it is only a warm-up.
articles.lead_paragraph: GREEN BAY, Wis. — “Recall Walker” bumper stickers dotted the workers’ parking lot at the Georgia Pacific paper mill on Day Street here one recent afternoon, proof of their union’s role in the effort to oust Gov. Scott Walker from office early for his legislation limiting public employees’ bargaining rights.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Steven Greenhouse

articles.headline: In Crisis Over Dissident, U.S. Sends Official to Beijing
articles.snippet: Days before scheduled talks between the United States and China, the Obama administration sought to contain the matter of an escaped activist who is said to be in American hands.
articles.abstract: Days before scheduled talks between the United States and China, the Obama administration sought to contain the matter of an escaped activist who is said to be in American hands.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration rushed to contain a growing diplomatic crisis between the United States and China, sending a senior diplomat to Beijing to discuss the fate of a blind dissident who fled house arrest last week.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Jane Perlez

articles.headline: In Vast Jungle, U.S. Troops Aid in Search for Kony
articles.snippet: A hundred of America’s elite Special Operations troops are helping African forces find a wig-wearing, gibberish-speaking rebel commander named Joseph Kony.
articles.abstract: A hundred of America’s elite Special Operations troops are helping African forces find a wig-wearing, gibberish-speaking rebel commander named Joseph Kony.
articles.lead_paragraph: OBO, Central African Republic — It has got to be one of the oddest matchups in United States military history.

articles.headline: Wal-Mart’s U.S. Expansion Plans Complicated by Bribery Scandal
articles.snippet: A scandal involving Wal-Mart’s Mexican subsidiary is giving critics of the company new reasons to push to block its expansion into big American cities.
articles.abstract: A scandal involving Wal-Mart’s Mexican subsidiary is giving critics of the company new reasons to push to block its expansion into big American cities.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Los Angeles, a Wal-Mart building permit is getting a once-over. In New York, the City Council is investigating a possible land deal with the retailer’s developer in Brooklyn. A state senator in California is pushing for a formal audit of a proposed Wal-Mart in San Diego. And in Boston and its suburbs, residents are pressuring politicians to disclose whether they have received contributions from the company.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Steven Greenhouse

articles.headline: Navigating a Tightrope With Amazon
articles.snippet: Buzz Bissinger’s postscript to “Friday Night Lights” was doing well as an e-book. Then a giveaway involving Apple and Starbucks became a pricing dispute with Amazon.
articles.abstract: Buzz Bissinger’s postscript to “Friday Night Lights” was doing well as an e-book. Then a giveaway involving Apple and Starbucks became a pricing dispute with Amazon.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last Tuesday, Buzz Bissinger hopped the Amtrak train to Philadelphia from New York, where he had done a bit of publicity for “After Friday Night Lights,” a 12,000-word e-book that had been performing nicely since its release. But when he opened his laptop to check his ranking on Amazon, he found the book was no longer for sale there.

articles.headline: Start-Ups Look to the Crowd
articles.snippet: The Pebble, a watch being developed to work with smartphones, has raised more than $7 million in financing on Kickstarter, a case that has signified the site’s coming of age.
articles.abstract: The Pebble, a watch being developed to work with smartphones, has raised more than $7 million in financing on Kickstarter, a case that has signified the site’s coming of age.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Eric Migicovsky, an engineer, wanted to develop a line of wristwatches that could display information from an iPhone — like caller ID and text messages — he went the traditional route of asking venture capitalists to finance his company.

articles.headline: Scandal and Scrutiny Hem In Murdoch’s Empire
articles.snippet: The phone-hacking scandal in Britain is taking a toll on Rupert Murdoch’s broader holdings, prompting worry at News Corporation that years of business dealings could draw new attention.
articles.abstract: The phone-hacking scandal in Britain is taking a toll on Rupert Murdoch’s broader holdings, prompting worry at News Corporation that years of business dealings could draw new attention.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the months after a phone-hacking scandal erupted in Britain last summer, Rupert Murdoch told people within News Corporation that he wanted to revisit his media company’s discontinued $12 billion bid for the pay television service British Sky Broadcasting.

articles.headline: In China, Foreign Films Meet a Powerful Gatekeeper
articles.snippet: The China Film Group functions as the Chinese government’s guardian of its film market, but now the group is also supervising a trade route suddenly under scrutiny from regulators in Washington.
articles.abstract: The China Film Group functions as the Chinese government’s guardian of its film market, but now the group is also supervising a trade route suddenly under scrutiny from regulators in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Any foreign movie knocking on China’s door must pass through powerful gatekeepers — the China Film Group and its chief executive, Han Sanping.
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and David Barboza

articles.headline: Ryan’s Rise From Follower to G.O.P. Trailblazer
articles.snippet: Representative Paul D. Ryan, the Republican Party’s de facto head of economic policy, may be one of its most important figures outside of Mitt Romney.
articles.abstract: Representative Paul D. Ryan, the Republican Party’s de facto head of economic policy, may be one of its most important figures outside of Mitt Romney.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Paul D. Ryan strolls the halls of Capitol Hill with the anarchist band Rage Against the Machine pounding through his earbuds.

articles.headline: Experts Believe Iran Conflict Is Less Likely
articles.snippet: With the revival of talks — which went unexpectedly well — and domestic differences arising in Israel, the odds of imminent conflict have decreased, experts and American officials say.
articles.abstract: With the revival of talks — which went unexpectedly well — and domestic differences arising in Israel, the odds of imminent conflict have decreased, experts and American officials say.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After a winter of alarm over the possibility that a military conflict over the Iranian nuclear program might be imminent, American officials and outside analysts now believe that the chances of war in the near future have significantly decreased.

articles.headline: Big Purses, Sore Horses and Death
articles.snippet: Large payouts to owners make it profitable for owners to field thoroughbreds that are past their prime, sometimes with fatal results.
articles.abstract: Large payouts to owners make it profitable for owners to field thoroughbreds that are past their prime, sometimes with fatal results.
articles.lead_paragraph: As he trained for his first race, at Aqueduct Racetrack in Queens, the 3-year-old thoroughbred Wes Vegas galloped on the track most mornings and had two timed workouts. But his handlers also prepared him in another way: In the month before the race, records show, he received 10 intravenous injections of potent drugs for pain, one the day before he ran; two injections of a drug for joint disease; corticosteroid injections in his two front ankles; a sedative; and an ulcer drug.
articles.byline: By JOE DRAPE, WALT BOGDANICH, REBECCA R. RUIZ and GRIFFIN PALMER

articles.headline: On a Tightrope, President Prods China on Rights
articles.snippet: President Obama pressed China on Monday to improve its record on human rights, while declining to discuss Chen Guangcheng, the blind lawyer who escaped house arrest.
articles.abstract: President Obama pressed China on Monday to improve its record on human rights, while declining to discuss Chen Guangcheng, the blind lawyer who escaped house arrest.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Monday gently prodded China to improve its human-rights record but pointedly declined to discuss the case of a prominent Chinese lawyer, Chen Guangcheng, now said to be under American protection in Beijing. His remarks highlighted the delicacy of an unfolding diplomatic dispute that analysts say may prove fiendishly difficult to resolve.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Andrew Jacobs
